questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.

After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.

You have computers that run Windows 11 as shown in the following table.

//IMG//


You ping 192.168.10.15 from Computer1 and discover that the request timed out.

You need to ensure that you can successfully ping 192.168.10.15 from Computer1.

Solution: On Computer1, you turn off Windows Defender Firewall.

Does this meet the goal?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
No (and this is not an easy question guys).

Note two important things about pinging machines:

Request timed out - You have outbound enabled to allow, the remote machine has inbound enabled to deny.
General failure - You have outbound enabled to deny. There is no need to talk about a remote machine in this case if yours is not sending.

So the problem is coming from the remote machine (Computer2).

comments.content: By default on Windows 10 and 11 ping replies will be blocked. To ensure a machine responds to pings an inbound ICMPv4 and/or ICMPv6 firewall rule must be created - ICMPv4 allows IPv4 replies and ICMPv6 allows IPv6 replies

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
Your network contains an Active Directory domain. The domain contains the users shown in the following table.
//IMG//

The domain contains a computer named Computer1 that runs Windows 10. Computer1 contains a folder named Folder1 that has the following permissions:
✑ User2: Deny Write
✑ Group1: Allow Read
✑ Group2: Allow Modify
Folder1 is shared as Share1$. Share1$ has the following configurations:
✑ Everyone: Allow Full control
✑ Access-based enumeration: Enabled
For each of the following statements, select Yes if the statement is true. Otherwise, select No.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
1. YES
2. YES
3. NO
Isnt the 3rd answer no, because its a hidden share due to $?

comments.content: agree. Access based enumeration doesn't matter in this case.

Now take notice that ABE works from the parent object to the child. If you enable share with $ it will hide, in this case, the parent folder (Folder1). The ABE will be activated for Folder1 and used inside it for its child objects not the parent it self.

We don’t know about the Folder1 parent object. One solution here would be activating ABE for the C drive (if it would be shared).

Reference: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5TzHP00Vxi0

You shouldn't forget this:

- ABE seeks to hide subfolders within folders. ABE is used only for displaying or hiding folders, not for controlling access, making Read access the only relevant permission for controlling display.
- $ hides folders mapped to the root regardless of who has read access to it.

You will never forget this:

ADE seeks to hide subfolders within folders.
$ hides folders mapped root.

discussion.content:
Third statement is NO

This question is trying to show us differences between using $ and the Access-based enumeration (ABE).

ABE is activated in the properties of any Folder Shared via Server Manager > File and Storage Services > Shares.

After activating this setting for the Folder you want, you will, then, be able to deal with the combination of Share+NTFS permissions. After setting up the combination permissions for a user or a group, those who doesn’t have at least Read access won’t see anything in the UNC path.

Answer is Y Y N, since Share1$ is a hidden share you need to access it with the direct path and it will not be visible when you access the computer. ABE only counts when you don't have any permissions on the folder which is nog the case here.

Pretty sure that access based enumeration is not the same thing as a hidden share. ABE hides a folder if a user doesn't have permissions to access it where as a hidden share using $ hides from everyone. So answers are Y Y Y

The 3rd answer is indeed no. I just tried it:
1. I shared two folders on mycomp: someshare$ and myshare
2. Entering net view \\mycomp at the command line only showed myshare
3. Entering \\mycomp in the Navigation Bar at the top of File Explorer only showed myshare
4. In the Navigation Pane (left pane) of File Explorer, opening Network --> mycomp only showed myshare
5. Actually entering \\mycomp\someshare$ in the File Explorer Navigation Bar opened directly into someshare$
Don't understand, how do you list files without using file explorer?

how is the first answer yes for listing files and folder when user only has read permission? Not read and list folders/subfolders. I thought read only allowed you to view contents of whatever file/folder that you were granted access to.

comments.content: neeever mind. permissions are cumulative. has modiy+read permissions o.O whoopsy :3
The question has stated the user only opened file explorer, without opening the direct path to the folder the folder will not be visible.

discussion.content: Could anyone confirm this answer?
Y-Y-N. User 3 can use the share. But he can not see the hidden $ share in explorer. He need the direct path.
Why is 2 YES. Doesn't DENY overrule all other permissions?

comments.content: Because Deny is applicable only write, but user2 can list the files in the share.

discussion.content: @Ramankatoch, Como tem toda essa certeza sobre a questão, pois no final do exame não é informado às questões que estão corretas ou incorretas?
Essa questão ficou muito dividida no gabarito, afinal qual seria a resposta e qual a justificativa? Após um debate de 20 comentários, o gabarito é o mesmo ou não?

I would go for YES YES NO.
They all can access as it is shared with everyone and there are NTFS permissions for both groups

When you share a folder and during the sharing you add the dollar sign at the end to it, it will be shared but NOT visible from File Explorer

The deny in the question is only a DENY WRITE but you can still read and see

I don't get this.
It looks like I am the only one who got this answer.
Folder 1 is shared so users will only get the lower permission
User 1 will end up with R
User2 will end up with R
User3 will end up with M 
so my answer is N,N,Y.

comments.content:
no you are not
I agree with YYN

discussion.content: Yes, yes, no$
Yes - Yes - No.
Tried and tested, was in Exam last Wednesday, the answer is correct!

comments.content:
The correct Awser is Yes, Yes and No for 3º.
I tested in lab with same descriptions of permissions, users and groups. User3 cannot se the Folder Share1$ when access \\Computer1 in file explorer.

discussion.content: User 1 has 'read' permissions which is lower than 'list files and contents' so why is 1 YES?

The share$ will hide a share irrespective if Access-based enumeration is enabled of not.
If Access-based enumeration is Enabled, the share will be hidden you a user does not have access to the share.
Share$ will hide the share even if Access-based enumeration is Enabled.
Thus: YES, YES & NO

comments.content: ANDREVOX's comment seems to be true, i've set this up in a test lab and User 3 can't see the Share$ folder

discussion.content: feel that it is yes,yes,no

I tested this. Enabled ABE on the shared folder and was not showing when using UNC path \\computername.. You need the specify the full path, even if ABE is enabled. ABE hides shares you do not have access to.

1. YES
2. YES
3. NO - trick question - the share is hidden with the $ - the share is still accessible but the user must know the full share path (this last question doesn't ask if the user can see "files" in the share - only if they can "see the share" after typing in the URL address for the PC). ABE does not apply

comments.content: *Q3 Side note: (share1 will be visible). it already gives you the answer.

discussion.content: everyone has full control. Access based enumeration only hides the folder if the users don't have read access. (basically what ThaMagnit said)

Access-based enumeration: Enabled
Users who has permission on the share will see the folder. 
everyone has full control

1. YES
2. YES
3. YES

1. Yes
2. YES
3. NO -- $ hides it from someone not local
Is it my imagination or did the comments disappear? I think it is yes, yes, no. Shares with $ on the end are hidden.

questions.answer_description:
Box 1: Yes -

Box 2: Yes -

Box 3: No -
Share1$ is a hidden share and is therefore not visible in File Explorer, even with access based enumeration enabled.
Reference:
https://www.varonis.com/blog/ntfs-permissions-vs-share/
http://www.ntfs.com/ntfs-permissions-file-advanced.htm
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/storage/dfs-namespaces/enable-access-based-enumeration-on-a-namespace

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Need to allow ICMPv4 Outbound

Selected Answer: B
The IP addresses specified are ipv4 addresses. Unless I'm missing something I don't see how allowing ipv6 traffic would help with a ping here.

comments.content: You are right my friend, the answer is NO. But if the question says "ping Computer2" then it would be right.

questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.

After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.

You have computers that run Windows 11 as shown in the following table.

//IMG//


You ping 192.168.10.15 from Computer1 and test timed out.

You need to ensure that you can successfully ping 192.168.10.15 from Computer1.

Solution: On Computer2, you allow incoming ICMPv6 traffic in Windows Defender Firewall.

Does this meet the goal?

Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.

After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.

You have computers that run Windows 11 as shown in the following table.

//IMG//


You ping 192.168.10.15 from Computer1 and discover that the request timed out.

You need to ensure that you can successfully ping 192.168.10.15 from Computer1.

Solution: On Computer2, you share a folder.

Does this meet the goal?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
When you share a folder the firewall rules that need to be open are:
- File and Printer Sharing (NB-Session-In)
- File and Printer Sharing (SMB-In)

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/storage/file-server/best-practices-analyzer/smb-open-file-sharing-ports
This would enable the rule File and Print Sharing (Echo Request - ICMPv4-In) which would allow you to ping the computer.

questions.question_text:
You have a Windows 11 Pro device.

You need to perform a scan in Microsoft Defender to check for rootkits.

Which type of scan should you use?

discussion.content:
To scan for rootkits in Microsoft Defender on a Windows 11 Pro device, you should use an offline scan.

An offline scan is a comprehensive and thorough scan that checks for rootkits and other deeply embedded malware that may not be detected by other types of scans. During an offline scan, the device is restarted and the scan is performed before the operating system and any malware can start.
